featuredReview.headline: Excellent space to level up

featuredReview.headline: Big, advantageous, but a bit slow
featuredReview.pros: There is a lot of opportunities that you could see in the business sector. Oracle as a leading company in this field has a lot to offer. In strategy level company is expanding aggressively to the cloud computer software services with it's advantages in terms of capital and scale. The core database business is not developing as fast as the emerging internet+ unicorns. The culture here is pretty friendly. You could meet different sorts of people. But the more aggressive ones often opt to join a more start-up based companies. You could have your own schedule to manage things. And it is more likely for you to have a good balance in work and life
featuredReview.cons: Some may say it's not as rewarding or as challenging as they want it to be. The hourly pay is definitely among the best...

featuredReview.headline: It will be bumpy
featuredReview.pros: Fast pace, tons of opportunities to learn. Best for new grad live in the city. Company provides free meals and good benefits.
featuredReview.cons:
Location is not ideal for south bay professionals, long hours and high stress, little to no work/life balance.  Increasing competition from other big tech names and auto manufactures.

You have higher chance to be successful if you:
- work hard, and proactively.
- always hustle, deliver faster than others
- pump in long hours in office and home
- are single, live in city (easier to put in more hours)
- worked with boss in the past, or maintain good relationship with bosses
- outspoken and well rounded when aligned with management, and keep quiet when not.
- rooted from VMware, Google, Facebook, Apple.

featuredReview.cons: Sometimes it feels like we're swimming upstream, but ultimately it just brings us closer together!

featuredReview.headline: Good people, great work-life balance
featuredReview.pros:
Good people, great work-life balance. Most people work from home 1 day a week. There is a lot of flexibility to work around any family commitments. Things are relaxed overall, but an impressive amount of work gets done.

There is a lot of room to move around. You can switch projects very easily if there is an opening and managers express a lot of (genuine) interest in your career goals.
featuredReview.cons:
The insurance business sounds boring, so the company is having a hard time hiring some top talent in some key areas.

There are some very good people, but overall technical skills are not as highly valued as more softer skills.

featuredReview.headline: Great place marred by a huge lack of morals at the top
featuredReview.pros: Smart, dedicated people.  Direct managers care, or at most seem to.  Above average benefits for the industry.  Smart people.  Great opportunity to advance to middle management.  Above average work life balance.  It would be the ideal place to work if not...
featuredReview.cons:
The people at the helm will gut engineering departments and replace them with engineers in Bangalore and/or Shanghai, or fresh out of school, to meet the bottom line and appease Wall Street.  They've done it before, they'll do it again. Beware.

If this company didn't own the DWG format they would have died decades ago.  AutoCAD profit has allowed them to buy their way into other industries, and gobble up competition, and then over time release those engineers and replace them with cheaper talent either overseas or right from school.  They have done this time and time again.  It's a modern day form of corporate raiding.

It is a terrible way to run a business, and it is a reason why they can't grow ANY software in house and have it succeed, outside of Autocad and it's verticals.  Virtually all successful products beyond these have been ACQUIRED, and of those products, at least 50% of the engineers are gone within 5 years.  It's sad, really.

featuredReview.headline: 5-star company
featuredReview.pros:
Yelp has an awesome company culture. It is a fun, open, and challenging work environment. There is a lot I could say, so I'll just start putting down bullet points:

* Excellent company values, particularly "play well with others". Most engineers at Yelp are friendly, helpful, and pretty easy to work with. Sure, there are some employees that don't adhere to this value, but in my experience many of these folks end up leaving Yelp.
* Great benefits. In addition to the standard health/dental, Yelp provides up to $60 per month for their wellness program, that can be used for gyms or other fitness activities. Additionally, the company has 3 two-day hackathons each year, where the engineers can work on whatever project they want. And, there are 4 "off-sites" each year where each engineering team goes to do something fun together, and 2 company-wide events per year. 
* A very open and accepting work culture. There were people at Yelp from so many different backgrounds. E.g. during lunch a muslim engineer would silent perform one of his daily prayer in the corner of the kitchen and everybody was cool with that. In 2015 Yelp officially participated in the SF pride parade. Yelp has at least a couple engineers with noticeable impairments and does a great job helping them to be happy, successful members of the team.
* Tons of awesome events, including learning lunches on Fridays (and sometimes Mondays too) with presentations on cool eclectic topics, movie nights, trivia nights, board games nights, women engineering groups, a variety of meetup events (e.g. python, machine learning), and more!
* Management is very open to ideas and supportive of work done by engineers. If you think of a cool, challenging project that benefits the company, chances are that you'll get to work on it.

I was not looking for another job when I left Yelp, and it was a tough decision to leave this company. I've worked or interned at 5 companies now, and I have been the happiest at Yelp.
featuredReview.cons:
There aren't many cons to working at Yelp as an engineer. However, now that the company is fairly big (4000-5000 employees) you cannot realistically expect rapid career advancement as you would at a successful, small startup unless you work really hard (I choose to maintain a good work/life balance and was very happy with that choice) or are ridiculously brilliant.

Along the same lines, the management claims that a well-performing engineer can be just as well compensated regardless of whether s/he pursues a path in management or remains a talented software engineer. However, based on my experiences I don't believe this is 100% true. Not that differing compensation is unreasonable, I just wish that management would not make this claim (unless I'm mistaken).

featuredReview.headline: This is the Beginning
featuredReview.pros:
Despite skepticism about unicorns and startups and an uncertain economic picture, Marketplace Lending is here to stay. When the dust clears from this down cycle, only a few players are going to remain, and Prosper is one of them. They have the size and execution that very few others do, and you'd be hard pressed to find another Valley startup that has as successful a product and as much room to scale in their market. 

It's not a question of growth. It's a question of meeting the challenge of continuing to grow so fast.

Having been an engineer at Prosper multiple years, I have seen it go through management changes and ups and downs. It hasn't always been easy. More than a few of the reviews on here reflect that struggle to find the right team to build a great engineering culture for long-term sustainable success. Through it all, the core executive team has demonstrated that they are thoughtful and patient and they value people, sometimes to a fault. And contrary to what some reviewers have said, they have the humility to admit that they are growing as leaders and sometimes make mistakes.

Now more than ever, that core team has the Product and Engineering leadership to really get it right. To address tech debt while delivering scale and doing what the business needs to weather a down market and emerge stronger.

There is no shortage of interesting problems to solve, and if you are a hungry talented person, you will get every chance to solve them.
featuredReview.cons:
- There is tech debt
- The product release process is cumbersome (but improving).
- State-of-the-industry best practices among developers are improving but unevenly distributed

Overall, for a ~700-person company, I found the perks provided to be excellent.

featuredReview.headline: unique place to work
featuredReview.pros:
Building the platform and the apps for the industrial internet is a huge challenge and nobody is better positioned then GE to do this. This is like a massively funded start up with a mission to really change the way the big machinery of the world works. There's nothing else like it in silicon valley so if the mission is important to you, this is a really unique situation to do something with massive potential.

The company is committed to getting this done and providing what it thinks it needs to make it so. Lots of money and growth being thrown at this.

The company is slowly figuring out that they need to make this much more like an actual software company and are gradually changing the facility to look and act that way, with snacks, pool tables and other amenities.
featuredReview.cons: No matter how much they try to sell it to us, this is not a start up inside a big company. It's many thousand people strong already and there are the inevitable big company politics that influence too much of the major decision making. Generally speaking the longer an exec has been with GE the less capable they seem to be at thinking lean or agile. Instead they look to add to their empires by adding more people to solve problems that are overblown. Fortunately they are slowly replacing these guys with more local talent that seems to have a better handle on building software at scale.

featuredReview.headline: Solid engineering talent and great technology
featuredReview.pros:
Despite recent attrition problems, there's still a solid core of engineering talent and a competitive product in the market. The scale is massive and the platform is complex. This means that it is an ideal place for someone looking to gain valuable experience playing with cutting edge technology and making a serious impact. Opportunities abound. Co-workers are pleasant and managers are down-to-earth.

Salary and bonus program is competitive. They also offer a good amount of stock options.
featuredReview.cons:
The aforementioned attribution problem, paired with some senior leadership changes over the past year (including a new CEO), means the organization has not been stable and morale is fragile. It can be tough emotionally if you've never experienced workplace turmoil before (especially for the impressionable young engineers). Some of the more experienced engineers have left for the likes of Facebook, which in a way validates the level of engineering talent.

Being a private company in adtech, it is hard to attach a value to the stock options if you are looking for a short-term pay-off.

featuredReview.pros:
Super smart, visionary people. Dont think I met any dummies there, ever. Very smart product and technology, ahead of its time.

I now work at Walmart after the acquisition, and I really miss Adchemy! I got an awesome package through the acquisition and feel like the management really took care of the people.
featuredReview.cons: Did not take care of operations nearly as well. Should have done less, slowed down and done things better.

featuredReview.headline: Software Developer Intern
featuredReview.pros: Good work culture, flexibility to move across teams and technologies, fun people to work with.
featuredReview.cons: Many people keep leaving the company due to some reason, the company isn't making much of a profit I think and hence salaries might be lower compared to others.

featuredReview.headline: Getting Better
featuredReview.pros: Finally some good leadership, great product that will get better this year, interesting projects, lots of ownership
featuredReview.cons: Too small of teams, seems like everything is being demanded without the required man power

featuredReview.headline: Fantastic Respect for Engineers, Sad SS&C Moved In
featuredReview.pros: My manager and teammates for the most part were incredible and so so knowledgeable, the benefits were amazing and the company really treated engineers and people in general with integrity and respect.
featuredReview.cons: There wasn't enough coding! Long periods without coding make engineers nervous because they feel like they're not providing value and improving their skill-set. And the different teams within the organization don't really get along which created a lot of bad overarching software decisions that eventually led to them being acquired.

featuredReview.headline: Relaxed and Productive Work Environment
featuredReview.pros:
Challenging and interesting project related to online education.
Relaxed work environment.
No bloated and unnecessary meetings.
Hands-off management style so you are not stressed out.
featuredReview.cons:
Benefits for employees with a large family is lacking compared against other large Bay-area tech companies.
You need to prepare your own lunch or go out, which consumes a lot of work hours in a busy San Mateo downtown.
Commute benefit is lacking.  i.e., no paid Caltrain pass.

featuredReview.headline: Getting to Done
featuredReview.pros: Fantastic place to work! The team is very cohesive, everyone is on the same page, all working together towards a single mission: helping customer get to done. There's a strong sense of impact on the company, team, and individual level which motivates you to continue delivering great work. Each individual is empowered to make decisions on how to tackle challenging problems. The focus is not only on company growth but also on individual growth and development. Best of all, an in-house culinary team making delicious and nutritious meals every day!
featuredReview.cons: For engineering, some grunt work involved in revamping old code to be cleaner and more efficient, although this itself is a good learning opportunity. In general, culture is starting to shift due to the fast growth (employee-wise), e.g. engineering citizenship in tackling the not-so-popular work is mostly done by the "long-timers" and not the newcomers, fading participation in brown bags and workshops. Still hoping for 401K matching, though it is mostly a perk at public companies (and not startups).

featuredReview.headline: Good balance of interesting work and life
featuredReview.pros:
The work life balance is the best.  The only time I have worked over 40 hours a week is when I wanted to.  There will be times when people feel the need to work overtime but it is not the norm.  
The problems are interesting and feel important.  Sure you can burn out on anything but there is a ton of interesting work at the lab.
On that note, the lab has so many projects going on that if you need something new after a few years you can find something fresh to re-invigorate you.
Finally the pay is pretty decent for the area.  Yes you will get more money at the big companies further west, but the cost of living around the lab is way more in line with lab salaries than with other companies.
Final advice, if you are a fresh grad and can grind for a bit, go to one of the big companies and make some serious dough.  If you appreciate work life balance, want to spend time with your family, and want a decent quality of life, this is a great place.
featuredReview.cons:
When it comes to software engineering the lab hasn't quite figured out how to define career paths yet.  They have a classification system worked out but it is only a few years new at this point and they are only just starting to define and coach employees on how one would get a promotion.
Being a government funded facility, we are at the mercy of the federal budget.  When stuff like the government shut down happens, or salaries are frozen for federal workers, it affects us.
The frills and niceties of other companies are non-existent here.  Here are some examples: when taking someone on a lunch interview, the lab will not do the courtesy of paying for your interviewees lunch, you have to pay out of your pocket;  Many buildings have cramped hallways and not so nice bathrooms (not gas station bathrooms, but not nice bathrooms); Many buildings have only basic custodial services, i.e. you'll be cleaning the fridge out yourself.

featuredReview.headline: A Mix of Good and not so good experience
featuredReview.pros:
There were days when the company was not acquired, those used to be golden days.
Each team was considered equally important. The focus was merely in achieving best product quality
featuredReview.cons: Senior management does not consider all teams as equal. There is a heavy bias on core team/product at the expense of overlooking activities by non-core team.

featuredReview.headline: Developer
featuredReview.pros: Knowledgeable colleague, enjoyable work, good energy.
featuredReview.cons: Hidden politics and crazy work hours that everyone complains about in 1:1 discussions. However people are too scared to complain openly for fear of reprisals. A few young people in their twenties took 2 weeks off (at various times) to recover from exhaustion and overwork.

featuredReview.headline: good work life balance
featuredReview.pros: Working at HP has a good work life balance. This is a pros for employees but probably a cons for the eimployers
featuredReview.cons:
politics kills performance. Most managers are not willing to learn technical stuff. Their jobs are just  
route the work to the engineers or push the jobs to other groups.

featuredReview.headline: Good people being led by people bad at what they do
featuredReview.pros: Folks below upper management are great, company mission is not evil, product ideas are mostly good
featuredReview.cons: Upper management stinks, product schedules are evil, product execution is mostly bad

featuredReview.headline: dreamy
featuredReview.pros:
- emphasis on mentorship and career growth
- getting to work on a meaningful product with positive impact on the world
- ... working with the types of coworkers that that attracts: thoughtful, collaborative, and bright
- does a great job of looking at your holistic self - I feel very recognized and appreciated for my talents outside of raw engineering
featuredReview.cons: mostly standard startup cons - not enough people to do all the meaningful stuff we want to do. but, the company is very open to you pursuing your passion projects, so things can get done if you really care about them.

featuredReview.headline: DevOps Intern 2015
featuredReview.pros: The people were fantastic.  Everyone is really positive and eager to lend you a hand if and when you need help.  There's plenty to learn there and plenty of opportunities to excel.
featuredReview.cons: The product itself may not be too interesting depending on your background and what you're looking for.

featuredReview.headline: So glad I found TellApart
featuredReview.pros:
Incredibly smart people. Impressed by the CEO (who knows the industry cold), the VP of Eng (strong technically and really cares about mentoring his engineers), and all the technical leads/managers. 

This is one of the rare companies that has <100 people but >$100M in revenue and real infrastructure problems (TBs of data per day, >200K QPS traffic/day). You get a ton of ownership of the problems and work at real Webscale. Not a dinky-little startup.
featuredReview.cons: The company is growing quickly and learning how to go from "small startup" to "medium-sized company". Communication isn't perfect yet.

featuredReview.headline: Great/Fun company!
featuredReview.pros: High energy, fun company to work for. Everyone really gets along with each other, very collaborative/cross-functional environment. Definitely recommend!
featuredReview.cons: Can get a bit hectic with the amount of growth company is going through. Have to jump through a decent amount of hoops to complete tasks

featuredReview.headline: Blank
featuredReview.pros: Great talent and smart people. Never a worry about grabbing coffee or lunch with a co worker as every one is friendly.
featuredReview.cons: Some turnover. Part of the burnt out old blood saying goodbye and the new energized new blood saying hello. It's not a bad thing.

featuredReview.headline: Good company
featuredReview.pros: Great work life balance, good benefits, some interesting projects. There seems to be a real investment in making the company attractive and a nice place to work.
featuredReview.cons: Nothing particular... it's a nice company

featuredReview.headline: Too big for "culture"
featuredReview.pros: This is the perfect work environment for someone who doesn't want to be challenged or noticed, and just wants to show up for a 9-5 job and get paid.
featuredReview.cons:
- Way past any exciting work left to do.
- Packed with older people with old-school work habits (complete opposite of a startup)
- No growth/challenges

featuredReview.headline: Great company, fun environment, team focused.
featuredReview.pros: Great place to work, fast paced but never feel too much high pressure. Everyone works together as a team to accomplish mutual goals. Friendly and easy going leaders who are always available to help you solve problems or just grow in your career. Lots of great perks (catered meals, rec area with ping pong and pool tables, monthly massages, etc.) and frequent team outings to keep the team growing as a living organism instead of individual entities.
featuredReview.cons: Sometimes communication can be a little slow to trickle down to the majority of employees.

featuredReview.headline: Twitch is passionate about their product!
featuredReview.pros: Great perks, great people, exciting work. Twitch is filled with people who really care about the product they're building, and that makes the work all that much more worthwhile. It's great to be part of a company that is transition from startup to a larger company; Amazon provides Twitch with support, but Twitch still retains the culture that made it unique in the first place.
featuredReview.cons: The company is going through some growing pains, but overall they have been relatively smooth. From an engineering standpoint, the biggest hurdle is digging through legacy code that nobody seems to know about, since all of the people that wrote said code are now in management roles or left the company after the acquisition.

featuredReview.headline: Great work life balance + culture
featuredReview.pros: I had an incredible experience at OpenTable! I had a lot of opportunities to choose +/ work on exciting individual projects that led me to believe that I was making an actual impact - meanwhile I also had a lot of help from fellow engineers + my manager whenever I needed it. At no point did I feel like I was doing pointless work. Lots of lovely, clever people. Great work life balance i.e don't expect to work for more than 8-9 hours. Location is perfect if you love the city. Also - as it shouldn't surprise you, people here are foodies! They love to wine and dine at good places. It's also an exciting time to be at OpenTable because it's growing a lot.
featuredReview.cons: Not the most hip tech company - overall employees are a little older than expected. (although I believe they are working on hiring more new grads + the HR team is working hard on bringing in that hip vibe).

featuredReview.headline: I love working at VSCO
featuredReview.pros:
If you care about visual art like I do there aren't many other places like VSCO that are genuinely dedicated to it and that successful at it. VSCO is a company that has discovered its identity and purpose, and the users have responded. 

The project is awesome and very ambitious.

The execs are pretty low key and not egotistic, which is huge in my book. Notice how they don't their face and bio on the company website? How awesome is that. VSCO aims to be a very employee oriented company and they mean it.

It's a young company so there is a wealth of opportunity for people joining now.

The benefits are great.

Incredible work environment, from the amazing office, the food, the perks, the benefits, the project, the quality of the people.

The downtown oakland location works great for me.
featuredReview.cons:
What makes VSCO great come at a price: It's still a young company with long term uncertainties, things change very quickly which can be unsettling for some people.

The location works for me but can be an issue if you leave in SF or the peninsula. Downtown Oakland is still "transitioning"...

Salaries are good but not industry top.

featuredReview.headline: Solid company
featuredReview.pros:
Good work life balance.  As a software engineer, sometimes you have to work longer hours to get things done on time, but it's never asked of you by management.  In my current project, I rarely work more than 40 hours per week.  Also, the company has been around for a long time and is very stable... it's never had a round of layoffs in the > 10 years I've been there.  Turnover is very low compared to traditional software companies.

One thing I really like about this company is the software is used in so many industries outside of the tech sector... primarily connecting to automation control systems used for manufacturing, oil and gas, energy production, chemical, pharmaceuticals etc.  Talking to our customers is like watching an episode of "How It's Made".  I've learned a lot.
featuredReview.cons:
The company does so well because it caters to a niche set of markets that have a lot of money.  It has few real competitors that can offer the same software and services.  However, if a big company with a lot of resources decided they wanted to compete in these markets, the company would probably be in trouble.

Also, from a software standpoint, much of the technology being used is somewhat dated (legacy stuff) without a lot of real interesting innovation happening in many dev groups.  There's some effort recently to change that however.

featuredReview.headline: Senior Software Engineer
featuredReview.pros: No Micro management. Very supportive colleagues.
featuredReview.cons: None. Management starts a project and scraps it just like that. Looks like they enough money to waste.

featuredReview.headline: Incredible culture, great opportunities
featuredReview.pros:
Credit Karma is fantastic because it tackles interesting technological questions at a great location with smart people who care about one another.

From an engineering perspective, we constantly have to tackle challenging problems. We build native applications for two mobile platforms and for the Web; we work with two credit bureaus and dozens of financial partners (and we're constantly onboarding more partners), each with its own APIs and technical demands; we constantly have to ensure the security of our users' personal information; and we're always building new features to provide the most comprehensive set of credit information on the Web. Each employee is given a stipend to attend (and is encouraged to apply to speak at) technical conferences.

As to company culture, we have perks and experiences that are tough to beat. Like most tech companies, we have fully-stocked kitchens (healthy and less healthy snacks, breakfast cereal, bagels, keg coolers for both beer and iced coffee, etc.) and game rooms (with multiple gaming consoles and a rotating set of vintage arcade games). We convert two of the kitchens into yoga studios twice a week for free yoga classes that are open to all employees. On Wednesday afternoons and Friday afternoons there are often happy hours or other events like trivia nights, movie nights, outings to the Giants game (with an opportunity to go out on the field beforehand during batting practice!), etc. In addition, we have regular company retreats - we did a day at the zoo back in October 2014, had a company Field Day in June (with sumo suits, bubble soccer, a pie eating contest, and more), and recently got to go to the batting cages in AT&T Park and meet Draymond Green after the JP Morgan Corporate Challenge road race.

Ultimately, though, your experience is defined by the people you work most closely with. Credit Karma's employees universally buy in to its culture - great work/life balance, celebrating each other's accomplishments, etc. To encourage team cohesion, teams (engineering and non-engineering) will go to nice dinners as a group and participate in other team-bonding events (one team is going sailing on the Bay later this week). On the rare occasions when a team member experiences a personal setback (illness in the family, injury, etc.), other members of the team will pick up the slack without question. That sense of giving spills over into the broader community: Credit Karma sponsors blood drives, toy drives, volunteering at coding camps for needy children, and other events that have an impact beyond its walls. Working in an office that promotes empathy, wellness, and happiness is a recipe for productivity and employee retention.
featuredReview.cons: Like any company that has old code and a larger engineering team, Credit Karma still has to deal with legacy code and with cross-team integration for software written by one team but consumed by another. In addition, although we have plenty of space, we're situated on two different floors in each of two different buildings; the two floors in the larger building are also not consecutive floors. It would be great if we could move into our own building or if we could have adjoining floors to facilitate cross-team participation.

featuredReview.headline: No work and no growth
featuredReview.pros: global brand but on its way down, had good potential but startup culture has deteriorated in past 2 years
featuredReview.cons: no strategy, employees play back door politics and nothing else. work is not rewarded but everyone pretends to work and plays politics

featuredReview.headline: Experiences of an Intern
featuredReview.pros: Fun place to work, smart people to learn from, and good food for catering. The office is in a convenient location, and has a great view of the Financial District. Though I expect this is true of SF in general, people there really believe in and support diversity.
featuredReview.cons: Fewer intern events throughout the term. "Hackternoons" seem unimportant, which undermines the startup culture. Sometimes politics allowed for less qualified people to be in roles they shouldn't have been in (and yes, even I, as an intern, noticed this).

featuredReview.headline: Small and tight company
featuredReview.pros: Engineering department is a close and tight group. Realistic work load. Transparent management at least when I was there
featuredReview.cons: Not much else going on besides work in the office. Not much cross department communication.

featuredReview.headline: Good place to learn
featuredReview.pros:
Opportunity to learn a lot about ad tech.
People, in general, help each other a lot. A few teams work really well with each other and are more like friends.
featuredReview.cons:
If you are not a developer then it is hard to get the recognition.
Working long hours is a given.
Not so many team outings !
401k matching could be better.

featuredReview.headline: H1-b Sweatshop
featuredReview.pros: Job stability.Strong Marketing team.Can't think of anything else.
featuredReview.cons:
H1-b sweat shop..Horrible place to work for IT folks..No planning from senior management.No work life balance for IT folks. If you want to spend your weekends working on legacy applications, this is for you. 
All the good reviews are from a recent email sent out to all employees to provide a review on Glass door. Most of the positive reviews are from Sales/Customer representatives who seem to be happy. I would not recommend this company  to anyone.

featuredReview.headline: title: Excellent environment to practice the pure craft of software development
featuredReview.pros:
Pair programming all day every day means that you will be learning and teaching constantly.  After four years, I'm still surprised nearly every day with how much I learn just by observing and interacting with my colleagues.  There are awesome catered breakfasts every morning, endless
snacks, and a whole group of superstars called the "Happiness team" who keep office life weird and awesome.  Work-life balance is a core benefit extended to every individual contributor on the floor.  Overtime is totally unheard of.  Your workday will start at 9am, end at 6pm, and your phone will never ring outside of work hours.

The company's core values are: "do the right thing", "do what works", and "be kind".  Management and labor in the Pivotal Labs organization (a services division inside of Pivotal), strive to live up to these lofty ideals and they succeed more often than not.  I've seen management on more than one occasion turn down business from clients who were unkind or unprofessional in sales meetings.  Since upper management has strong positive and negative incentives to bring in business, turning away a client who is likely to make the Pivots on the floor unhappy is a strong signal that management truly does take the long view and values the creation of a nurturing and sustainable workplace environment over short-term gains.

Occasionally you will be staffed on a very challenging project with a client who doesn't fully see the value of some of our more esoteric practices.  You'll sit next to passive-aggressive client developers who will complain bitterly about writing tests, or pairing, or just want to do things their own way.  Try and treat these engagements as the learning and growth opportunities they are.  Make sure that you are truly empathizing with your "difficult" clients (or difficult co-workers) and bring an attitude of humility and willingness to change your opinion when faced with facts, like for instance, the fact that despite writing a lot of tests a product still has frequent regressions when new features are added, etc.  Weekly retrospectives are an opportunity to speak directly with your product team about what's not going well and how to immediately change your team's process to make it better.  Over time I've learned that being direct (remembering also to be kind), is almost always the best approach.  In most cases, even on the most challenging projects I've worked on, clients eventually see the value of some parts of our process and come to adopt them.

In summary, Pivotal Labs is a fantastic place to work and I've benefited tremendously from my time there.  I highly recommend it as a workplace for software developers who want to learn a process for continuously improving their craft.  If you come in with an open mind, you will grow tremendously in technical ability and in the ability to empathize with your clients and co-workers.
featuredReview.cons: Salaries lag behind industry standard.  I've seen many of the most talented employees leave because they felt their professional development wasn't progressing rapidly enough.  These folks in many cases were among the most productive members of the office.  People coming and going is normal for a consultancy, perhaps it's just the name of the game, but I suspect that more could be done to retain our best folks.

featuredReview.headline: Inventing the Future of Healthcare
featuredReview.pros: Great strategy and many good initiatives addressing the challenges of a changing healthcare environment - cost pressures, aging population, consumerization.
featuredReview.cons: Lots of changes, people, organization, hard to keep up. There are a lot of good intentions for training, career opportunities, growth, but it's much more important to network internally.

featuredReview.headline: Great place, smart people.
featuredReview.pros: Extremely smart people, collaborating to create movies that are widely loved.
featuredReview.cons: No career path. Existing employees taken for granted.

ceo.name: Ed Catmull
ceo.title: President, Pixar and Disney Animation Studios

featuredReview.headline: ROBLOX - Great Place to Work
featuredReview.pros: Wonderful community, great coworkers, amazing vision, and a lovely location.
featuredReview.cons: The product's community isn't the best, as some of the players of the game aren't very mature.

featuredReview.headline: Really Great Place to Work
featuredReview.pros:
- Very disruptive idea and platform, current leader in its domain
- Engineering places high value on good programming practices, innovation, and experimentation. I am learning at an exponential rate working here. Work is actually fun and challenging
- Change in the company's vision a couple years ago made Enterprise the focus and we are now skyrocketing. Management is very transparent with their goals, revenues, and costs. We know exactly which direction we are heading each month, and it's up
- Maintains a great startup culture and environment (just take a look at the photos) but with the maturity and direction of a larger company
- Great benefits, flexible hours, good vacation policy
featuredReview.cons:
- Only free catered lunch 3 days of the week (first world problems)
- Salary is competitive, but it's no Google... yet
- No 401k matching

featuredReview.headline: Life at Lyft
featuredReview.pros: The work you do impacts the lives of people. When you take a Lyft and talk to drivers/passengers; you get such good reviews that motivate you to do more. The people that work at Lyft are amazing, they are always willing to help you out whenever. The food is amazing too.
featuredReview.cons: I am yet to come across any major con during my time here. The company is getting huge is you consider that a con

featuredReview.headline: Depends on your team
featuredReview.pros: Great work-life balance. Rarely feels like crunch-time.
featuredReview.cons: FactSet is a very large company with many teams working on many different things, so your experience will largely depend on your team and your manager. My manager tended to micromanage and our relationship was prone to communication issues. I also happened to be working on technology that was nowhere near "cutting edge," so I burnt out rather quickly. Compensation is a bit below industry average, but FactSet somehow continues to find good people who are willing to work for that salary.

featuredReview.headline: Software
featuredReview.pros: Beautiful place to work.  Most of the people are bright, competent and friendly.  The software projects are interesting. You get to see how your work helps the business partners.  Ergonomics of the furniture in your cubicle will be great.
featuredReview.cons: 5.5' x 8' cubicles.  Management is kind of confused.  They will send you to weeks of classes on subjects like agile projects and then tell you not to use it.  They will tell you things in interviews that either don't turn out to be true or that don't happen once you get hired.  They put micro-managers in who will tell you to do a project and then try to manage it from above or around you - getting resources involved at inappropriate times, telling others to do something on a project you're supposed to be managing.   software engineers will end up with projects where they have all the responsibility for success and no way to get cooperation from the other people/groups.  There was no IT function for a long time, so there were people programming who shouldn't have been and there is a lot of 'quick and dirty' stuff in every environment you can name.  If you don't have a car, just getting there can be a pain. Plan on spending quite a bit of time standing on a street corner in Berkeley or a BART platform or at a bus stop on the hill.   Benefits are good, salaries are so-so and raises are rare and small.

featuredReview.headline: Good Consulting Company
featuredReview.pros: Not much Process or Bureaucracy. As long as client is paying you, no one would bother you.
featuredReview.cons: Growth Scope is negligible. You end of working at client site for years. Not much emphasis on Training and Development. Its mostly a self learning environment.

featuredReview.headline: Good but not fulfilling enough
featuredReview.pros:
Good compensation and great benefits, the company makes tons of cash so it's being very generous on annual bonuses, it even has a cash-equivalent Employee Stock Program. Significant annual increases pretty much guaranteed if you're a decent enough achiever, so even if you start average it can climb pretty quickly.

Great morale, it helps to work on an industry leading console which blows records month after month. Awesome to be able to show people your work on your PS4 at home.

Nice people overall, very laid back atmosphere, lots of video games and Japan enthusiasts. Good diversity and very respectful atmosphere among employees (no brogrammers)
featuredReview.cons:
A lot of mediocrity among engineers: some of them barely knew how to program, others would spend more time on social media than working, or even some more interested in running their own interests before their assignments. If you end up locked up in one of these teams, it's very hard to get out.

Also lots of politics going on, way too much for me. I was also not a big fan of the widespread SAFE methodology and the over-reliance on tools like Rally which created lots of overhead. 

Working with Japan is interesting  but also very frustrating at times, especially as they have ownership of the platform.

Finally, very limited remote work options, given that most of the work requires devkits that can't be accessed outside the office.

featuredReview.headline: The company is good but the management is just bad
featuredReview.pros:
I joined the company as a new grad engineer. Glassdoor is a great company. I can't think of how someone can go through a job seeking process without using Glassdoor. I love the company and it was the reason I chose it over other offers I had at the time. But I wish I could have a better manager. I don't wish to be in another team because all my teammates are knowledgeable and fun to work with. It's just weird how a manger of a hard core back end team doesn't like coding and spent most of his time in meetings without implementing any important piece of code while the company is still a startup. It's ok to be in meetings but it's not right when you are an engineer lead and have more meetings than your project manager. Yes we have a PM. All the team members could see the problem, brought it up but nothing changed. I don't want to go in more details, but I do want to see Glassdoor successful. Look back at the journey I had at Glassdoor, I do realize I learnt many things from my teammates. I'm glad to know and have them in my life. I don't regret my choice, I just wish it could be better for everyone. 

To any new grad: choose your manager for your first job, it should be the highest priority because he/she will be your mentor (or no mentorship at all if you choose a wrong one).
featuredReview.cons: I want to say management, but I can't really say so because I only experienced it in my team. Maybe managers of other teams are better.

featuredReview.headline: Definitely on the right track
featuredReview.pros: Very competitive salary. Product is without peer in the web conferencing space. Clear chain of command with supportive managers and executives. Easily the most rewarding decision I've made was coming here.
featuredReview.cons: The 401k situation could be better. High turnover at times has lowered bandwidth for those employees who remain, but that seems to be improving.

featuredReview.headline: A Bad Place for Women in Tech
featuredReview.pros: A comfortable place for white old males to retire.
featuredReview.cons: A punch of white males over 40 running the company. Zero % woman in upper technology management positions. Women are populated in submissive administrative positions, such as Executive Admins.

featuredReview.headline: Mixed bag
featuredReview.pros: Great focus on culture. Strong, capable team. Sincere belief in vision of saving lives through making the best EHR for doctors.
featuredReview.cons: Serious executive missteps. Recent layoffs have shaken trust in the company. Oversized egos and rampant title inflation in engineering department make advancement difficult.

featuredReview.headline: Culture counts
featuredReview.pros: The people and the culture. Genuinely open, family friendly and relentlessly positive. I've never worked for a company so invested in what their people bring to the role. The company also  encourages (and gets wide participation from its employees) in voluntary work in the community and I've been surprised how much I've enjoyed that aspect to working there. I'm genuinely a better person for having worked there.
featuredReview.cons: For many, agile at Gap is at best a prescriptive set of tasks to be performed rather than something that is genuinely adaptive. Transient project teams with heavy contractor:FTE ratios mean that the emphasis is too often to design for the immediate task and the minimum viable employee.

featuredReview.headline: Takes a special personality to work here
featuredReview.pros:
I feel trusted here to make game and business impacting decisions. I feel like I'm treated like an adult.
LGBT friendly
Truly unlimited PTO/sick leave. People have taken month long vacations and have come back more recharged than ever.
Compensation is highly competitive. Kixeye is the first company I've ever worked at I got raises within six months of starting out. You need to demonstrate what you bring to the company. No one will just hand out a raise.
featuredReview.cons:
Culture of fear is still very real here. 
Not everyone is cut out for the high stress environment at Kixeye.
You need a Type A+ personality to work here.
High turnover impacts game teams. Management is reluctant to fill much needed open positions.
Management doesn't understand opportunity cost. Those unfilled positions cost a lot of time and stress on the rest of the team. Software gets written internally when commercial off the shelf solutions would of saved time and total expense. 
Game studios business model - game teams are fighting each other and having competition over resources when we should all be wanting the same goals.
No support for professional development such as attending non-local conferences. They do have a couple of team passes for GDC you can share.

featuredReview.headline: Great People
featuredReview.pros:
I have been working at location labs for two months now.  This has been the best work culture i have been part of.  I feel extremely valued as an employee.  Everyone I work with is smart and motivated.
    
The software engineering process they have implemented is great at getting the most out of employees.  I have grown and learned a tremendous amount in the last two months, and I can only see myself growing more in the coming future.
featuredReview.cons: The company is growing quickly, so there are a lot of changes.  This can be a positive in software engineering, but it can be difficult for new employees who are getting used to the system.  The on-boarding process for new engineers (especially those with limited experience) could definitely be overhauled.  A lot of being successful in a new company is learning from a great mentor.  However, if that mentor is bogged down with work it can be difficult for them to spend the appropriate amount of time training a new hire.

featuredReview.headline: Great Place to Work
featuredReview.pros:
Pros: Small company, you know when you have made a contribution.  You get the opportunity to work on projects from end to end.  

Culture, tools and processes are evolving from a startup level to scale up the company, so there is the opportunity to influence creation of the work environment that you want to work in.
featuredReview.cons:
Too many snacks in the break room, they try to make it healthy by proving fruit, but I eat the candy bars.  Hours can be long.

Tools and processes are evolving from a startup level to scale up the company, so you cannot relay on having all the tools in place without helping bring up the tools.

featuredReview.headline: Healthy culture and great people
featuredReview.pros:
There is a clear mission behind the company and everything we do daily adds up to customer satisfaction and recurring orders as well as well-being of our freelancers pool. Growth rate year after year shows that our work pays off. 

The in-house culture feels like home - you know everyone and you can talk to anyone freely and openly. There is no behind the scene politics or strict requirements for schedule, location, PTOs, etc. 

Hiring smart friendly people and giving them enough autonomy works for Rev so far. I couldn't imagine company may have such a healthy climate inside. 

You commit to some change in the product, and you make it happen. Nobody just hands you an issue with a deadline. Team responsibility, planning and estimation makes a great foundation to not stressing about work beyond work time. At this size and structure of product teams we can roll with the punches and release regularly. I really hope company growth won't complicate the structure we have now significantly.

One of the biggest benefits for me - you work alongside senior engineers with years of experience, so learning never stops.

After all of this, I can easily skip many small perks which many cool companies around have.
featuredReview.cons: No quick career jumping into leads - you should earn every next level with years of hard work.

featuredReview.headline: Good company but could be better
featuredReview.pros:
Great leadership, easy going and logical without any politics at engineering level. 
Really interesting and challenging problems that we have to solve from time to time. 
Growing (albeit slowly) company which is not afraid to change. 
No quarterly losses in more than 10 years. This company handles crises very well.
Flexible work schedule, good work-life balance.
For people living in Peninsula and commuting by car Daly City is probably the best location in Bay Area.
featuredReview.cons:
Genesys is in the holding pattern at the moment and we do not hear much about new big plans. Apparently current owner is trying to sell the company and management just does not want to make any significant moves.
Engineering salaries are pretty low but engineers over 40 should be happy just to have a job in Bay Area.
Extremely difficult to get new hardware. 5 year old desktops and even older monitors are the norm and if something happens to your computer then it is easier to go and buy your own than to deal with whoever should be in charge.
Without engineering day we would not even know what other engineers are doing.

Insufficient barriers to using all staff for sales activities and then trying to hold to existing deadlines. Few equity events for common staff - no bonus plan, no revenue sharing. featuredReview.headline: Mission-driven startup with brilliant people
featuredReview.pros:
1) LendUp is a technology-driven company, something that many companies claim but not all are. Account managers aside, engineers make up roughly 50% of the workforce.

2) Our social mission is very clearly the top priority and last say in decision-making. It is really easy to see the passion some of my coworkers have for making a difference in our customers' financial lives. It is personally incredibly rewarding to be working for a company that is actually making a huge difference.

3) The people here have that rare combination of brilliance and approachability. Regular brown bags, design reviews, retros. Sasha, the CEO, regularly sits down to eat lunch with new people.

4) This is a fast-paced environment where everyone has a great deal of responsibility and impact on the product. New hires can start shipping code on day 1. Employees are encouraged to voice their opinions, questions, and concerns regularly and there are many safe channels to do so

5) Comp and benefits are pretty good (not Google/Twitter good but hey, we're a startup). Everyone gets equity

6) Unlimited vacation if you get your work done

7) Diversity! Our engineering team is surprisingly eclectic and range from all walks of life
featuredReview.cons:
Minimal handholding/onboarding process can be tough for more junior folks. New hires are expected to take initiative and get their feet wet immediately - can be interpreted as a pro.

No annual bonus (yet)

featuredReview.headline: Bracket is truly the worst company ever #1.8RatingFTW
featuredReview.pros:
Not many pros.

Easy to get a job - they're desperate for people.  First job here better than nothing? If you can get out within a year or two then it might be OK, otherwise it will do your career more harm than good.

Job security - since they're desperate for people and no one(the good ones anyway) wants to work for them the job is yours.  Really tough for them to fire anyone.

Location - lots of places around to eat

Benefits - OK

PTO's - not bad
featuredReview.cons:
Will do your career more harm than good.

Too much work for too little pay.  Firemen get paid more, plus overtime, to put out less fire than Bracket employees.

Unequal distribution of work.  Good people given more work(including those of the bad ones), bad ones continue to get paychecks.  Good people quitting in droves.  

Heard of Amazon?  Sure you've heard about Amazon's terrible place to work news story recently.  
As bad as Amazon is it still has a Glassdoor rating of 3.4.  
Bracket has a Glassdoor rating of 1.8 on 95 reviews.  
Worst company ever.

featuredReview.headline: Great Place to work
featuredReview.pros: This is a great place to work! Working at this company was my first introduction to the Software Engineering Industry and it was a very welcoming place. I was part of the Road Crew program and they really work hard to make sure the interns feel a part of the company! You meet and talk to all the leaders of the company including the co-founder Tim Westergren. I loved working here because I think it is a well balanced company. There are a variety of people of all ages and to me that shows that the work life balance is great.
featuredReview.cons: In the beginning I felt lost when setting up my environment and I felt that my team was too busy to help me, but they were really busy and I had to learn not to be afraid to ask questions. When I did ask they were always willing to help me!

featuredReview.headline: Open flexible environment
featuredReview.pros: Vevo lets you take on as much challenge as you want, and there are lots of new things unfolding here:  new cross-platform features, new platforms all in a rapidly growing profitable company.  Vevo has more video views per month that all but a small number of companies, so knowing your work touches millions every day is exciting, but Vevo is still small enough the organization is still fairly flat, everyone has a say, and you will not be held back by anything if you want to tackle tough problems.  Most people here do not let ambition get in the way of having fun, however, so there is a certain laid-back vibe, with music playing a lot in the background, lots of ping pong games and socializing.  So there's a range of experiences here, depending on what each person wants out of their job.  Salary and benefits are very competitive.
featuredReview.cons: The usual challenges:  company has grown very fast so systems are not always built out as well as we would like (but no one will stop you from taking the initiative to fix them, unlike some companies).  Communication between technical teams in different offices still leaves a lot to be desired, and roles & responsibilities between groups could be better defined -- some important work slips through the cracks because no one seems to own it.  The profit sharing plan does not offer the same upside as equity in a start-up; then again, this company that's already profitable, and most start-ups never get there, so you just need to decide what's important to you.
